presentation.title: Introduction
presentation.toc: APIs increasingly become the connective tissue of the Web in general, and the way how business is looking at their IT strategy and structure in particular. APIs are what both separate and connect collaborating and communicating peers: They facilitate loose coupling of service providers and consumers and thus strike a balance between the ability to collaborate and cooperate, while still maintaining independence and individual control.

presentation.title: Microservices
presentation.toc: Microservice Architecture and Microservices embrace a new style of IT development and culture that focuses on speed, safety, robustness, and scalability. Taking the ideas of agile development, CI/CD, and DevOps one step further, microservices embrace organizational changes as well, so that improved IT processes are not compromised by the side-effects of organizational realities.

ul.li: IT is the/a key factor for organizational fitness and sophistication
IT complexity increases, yet IT velocity should increase as well
IT landscapes need to adapt to shifting organizations/partners/strategies
The line between internal and external IT is increasingly blurred/shifting
Top-down design and control of complex systems is problematic

Make system components self-contained, self-sustaining, and independent
Cultivate organizational structures aligned with system boundaries

Enforce system separation by disallowing shortcuts
Focus on team size and service scope to keep size small
Focus on effective ways to speed up service delivery
Focus on standalone-ability throughout a service's lifecycle
Focus on ecosystems of services to improve overall robustness
Focus on loose coupling so that the ecosystem is resilient

slide.title: One Definition: Goals
slide.blockquote: An architectural style for building solutions as network-based systems of services modularized by domains in order to improve the solutions’ evolvability, deployability, composability, scalability, resiliency and replaceability.

slide.title: Another Definition: Methods
slide.blockquote: A microservice is an independently deployable component of bounded scope that supports interoperability through message-based communication. Microservice architecture is a style of engineering highly automated, evolvable software systems made up of capability-aligned microservices.

presentation.title: API Design
presentation.toc: Microservice Architecture is about loose coupling, making sure that every service is entirely self-contained and can only be interacted with through its API. Another important aspect of that architectural style is that designers and developers have a lot of autonomy when it comes to designing, developing, and deploying their services. For this reason, API design for microservices must specifically target the diversity and decentralization that are inherent properties of any microservices landscape.

presentation.title: API Management
presentation.toc: API management needs to work both on a technical as well as on an organizational/cultural level. For the technical level, The most challenging factor in large API landscapes are the number of services, the rate of change, and the diversity of API designs in that landscape. API management needs to be able to deal with these factors in ways which do not inhibit the organic growth of the API ecosystem, while still maintaining a level of oversight and monitoring that make it possible to support data-driven decision-making.

presentation.title: API Security
presentation.toc: API security is not fundamentally different from general business security concerns: It is about how to balance the ease of access and use, and the risk of attacks and accidental misuse. Treating APIs strategically means to have policies and tooling in place that can be places around individual APIs, or some API perimeters. These policies and tooling will have to support the traditional security functions of identification, authentication, authorization, and encryption.

ul.li: Security is more than securing against external attackers
Security generally aims at identifying and mitigating risks
APIs add security surfaces that don't exist in integrated monoliths

Security needs a lot of real-time data to be effective

presentation.title: API Evolution
presentation.toc: API landscapes are constantly evolving: New APIs are added, existing APIs change, and established APIs are deprecated and eventually retired. API Evolution requires to have a set of practices that support all these activities. These practices should be easy to follow, should be visible through the APIs themselves, and thus allow the landscape to make its own evolution visible and manageable.

presentation.title: API Product Management
presentation.toc: Looking at an API First approach, API product management is not that much different from product management in general. Starting from this assumption, it needs to focus on the traditional tasks of planning, forecasting, and production, and marketing of a product. With a focus on microservices, these tasks are more easily to accomplish than with a more monolithic approach, because MSA provides more freedom to make these decisions on a per-product basis.

The main organization for Internet standards
Many of the fundamental pieces of Internet/Web architecture are IETF work
Internet Protocol (IP): The foundation on which the Internet is based
Domain Name System (DNS): The address book of the Internet that manages all names
Transmission Control Protocol (TCP): The reliable end-to-end protocol connecting applications
Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): The way in which Web resources are identified and addressed
Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP): The protocol spoken by all server and browsers and many APIs and apps
JavaScript Object Notation (JSON): The metamodel used for most modern API designs
Keeping an eye on ongoing developments are part of solid API management
The main organization for Web-related standards
Many of the fundamental pieces of Web architecture are W3C work
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML): The document format used by browsers
Cascading Style Sheets (CSS): The layout language supported by all modern browsers
Extensible Markup Language (XML): A metamodel still popular for some APIs
Resource Description Framework (RDF): A metamodel popular for a certain class of applications
Keeping an eye on ongoing developments are part of solid API management
The foundation of an API landscape is a mix of various standards
Many of the foundations are from IETF/W3C
Depending on the domain/industry, there may be other well-known foundations
webconcepts.info provides a starter pack of concepts
Currently listing 522 values classified in 16 different Web concepts
Create your own foundation by forking, removing, and adding concepts and values
APIs and the concepts they use should be linked both ways
Imagine having a dashboard of foundations and their popularity

Decouple signals, harvesting/collection, and analysis and decision-making
Treat API landscape instrumentation as one strategic focus
